thread.title: California woman killed in ice- caves collapse was on ‘much-needed vacation’
thread.title_full: California woman killed in ice- caves collapse was on ‘much-needed vacation’ | The Seattle Times

author: Seattle Times staff
title: California woman killed in ice- caves collapse was on ‘much-needed vacation’
text:
On her Facebook page, Anna L. Santana recently described her trip to Washington as “a much needed vacation.”
But officials confirmed Thursday that the Southern California woman’s life ended on the trip in Monday’s partial collapse of the Big Four Ice Caves in the Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest.
Santana, 34, a mother of four from Moreno Valley, died from injuries to her head and torso after a portion of the main cave collapsed on Monday afternoon , the Snohomish County Medical Examiner’s Office said Thursday. Her death has been ruled an accident.
Five others were injured. According to KING-TV, they include one of Santana’s children; her fiancé, Dustin Wilson; and her brother, David Santana.
Most Read Stories Anna Santana’s child has been released from the hospital.
Wilson, 35, also of California, remains hospitalized at Harborview Medical Center.
David Santana, 25, is listed in critical condition in the hospital’s intensive-care unit, hospital spokeswoman Susan Gregg said Thursday.
Two others hurt during the cave collapse have been treated and released from hospitals.
Santana’s body was recovered Tuesday afternoon, nearly 24 hours after the collapse because of the treacherous conditions in the rapidly melting caves.
According to an online funeral fund set up by a friend, Santana was “on a mini vacation visiting her family in Washington” when she was killed.
“She leaves behind 4 kids; 2 girls an(d) 2 boys ages 14, 12, 8 and 1,” the donation page on gofundme.com states. “We need all the help we can get to give her the proper burial she deserves and also to help her children.”
Santana worked at Inland Valley Oral Surgery, according to The Press-Enterprise newspaper of Riverside, Calif. Employees declined to talk about Santana, citing the family’s wishes.
No one was at her home Thursday, the newspaper reported.
On June 30, Santana made a post on her Facebook page from Ontario International Airport, telling her friends: “Washington bound for a much needed vacation.”
She arrived in Washington on July 1, some 18 hours after she was scheduled to land, her Facebook page said.
“After 21 hours we finally made it when our flight should have had us here in 3 hrs,” she wrote on her timeline. “Guess that’s how long it takes when u miss ur transfer flight : / turning over a new leaf early from now on!!”
The posting appeared with a photograph of Santana sitting in a wheelchair, surrounded by four children. When several of her Facebook friends wondered why she was in the wheelchair, Santana responded:
“I was just sitting in it cuz it was thr and man after a 20 flight w 4 kids I was exhausted.”
On July 3, Santana also posted a message on the Facebook page of Wilson: “Babe u will not believe how beautiful it is up this way,” it says.
Access to the Big Four Ice Caves remains closed indefinitely.
“We don’t have a date for (reopening) at this time,” Aleta Eng, a spokeswoman for the Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest, said Wednesday. “At this time, management wants to assess the caves for safety. There has not been a decision as yet as to when to reopen them.”
Geologists say this winter’s lack of snow and the recent warm temperatures led to the deadly collapse .
Snohomish County officials had warned visitors in May to exercise extreme caution near the ice caves, which are a popular hiking destination, because warm weather was causing sections of the caves to collapse.
The sheriff’s office said in May that visitors should stay on the trail and not stand on top of caves.
Visitors to the caves Sunday captured video of a large shelf of ice breaking free from a lip hanging over the entrance to the caves, scattering a small group of hikers who had wandered close.
Santana is the third person to die at the ice caves since 1998.
On Aug. 2, 1998, Catherine Stockton Shields, 27, of Bothell, died when part of the main cave fell on her .
On July 31, 2010, 11-year-old Grace Tam of Lake Stevens was killed by a car-sized boulder of ice while she posed outside the caves for a photograph.
